item.description:
L1 - Welcome to PSYC 1101

September 11, 2020

Prologue/Appendix B

Went over Syllabus

Link to Textbook Notes Only exterior platform use!

L10 - Sensory Systems 3 & Learning/Mem 1

October 16, 2020

Chapter 6-8

what is memory and how is it measured?
memory
the persistence of learning over time through the encoding, storage, and retrieval of information
what are measures of retention?
recall
retrieving information that is not currently in you conscious awareness but that was learned at an earlier time; fill in the blank
recognition
identifying items previously learned; multiple choice question
relearning
learning something more quickly when you learn it a second or later time
if you want to be sure to remember what you're learning for an upcoming test, would it be better to use recall or recognition to check your memory?
recall because your retention of the material is better than if you could only recognize it
how do psychologists describe the human memory system?
what is encoding?
the processing of information into the memory system
what is storage?
the process of retaining encoded information
what is retrieval?
the process of getting information out of memory storage
what is parallel processing?
the processing of many aspects of a problem simultaneously; the brain's natural mode of information processing for many functions
what is the 3 stage model of the memory-forming process?
    record to-be-remembered information as a fleeting sensory memory
    process information into short-term memory, where we encode it through reherarsal
    information moves into long-term memory for later retrieval
what is working memory?
a newer understanding of short-term memory that focuses on conscious, active processing of incoming auditory and visual-spatial informational and of information retrieval from long-term memory
what two new concepts update the classic three-stage information processing model?
we form some memories through automatic processing without our awareness, this model focused only on conscious memory; the newer concept of working memory emphasizes active processing
what are 2 basic functions of working memory?
active processing of auditory and visual-spatial information and focusing our spotlight attention
how do explicit and implicit memories differ?
what are explicit memories?
the facts and experiences that we can consciously know and declare
what is effortful processing?
how we consciously process explicit memories
what are implicit memories?
retention of learned skills or classically conditioned associations independent of conscious recollection
what is automatic processing?
unconscious encoding of implicit memories
what information do we process automatically?
space, time, and frequency
how does sensory memory work?
what is iconic memory?
a momentary sensory memory of visual stimuli; a photographic or picture-image memory lasting no more than a few tenths of a second
what is echoic memory?
a momentary sensory memory of auditory stimuli; if attention is elsewhere, sounds and words can still be recalled within 3 or 4 seconds
what is the capacity of our short-term and work memory?
what is the difference between automatic and effortful processing and what are some examples of each?
automatic processing occurs unconsciously for such things as the sequence and frequency of a day's events and effortful processing requires attention and awareness like when we work hard to learn new material in class
at which of the three memory stages would iconic and echoic memory occur?
sensory memory
what are some effortful processing strategies that can help us remember new information?
what is chunking?
organizing items into familiar, manageable units; oftens occurs automatically
what are mnemonics?
memory ais, especially those techniques that use vivid imagery and organizational devices
what is the spacing effect?
the tendency for distributed study or practice to yield better long-term retention than is achieved through massed study or practice
what is the testing effect?
enhanced memory after retrieving rather than simply rereading information
what are the levels of processing and how do they affect encoding?
what is shallow processing?
encoding on a basic level based on the structure or appearance of words
what is deep processing?
encoding semantically based on the meaning of the words; tends to yield the best retention
which strategies are better for long-term retention?
spreading out learning over time and repeatedly testing yourself
what is the capacity of long-term memory? are our long-term memories processed and stored in specific locations?
despite the brain's vast capacity, we do not store information as libraries store their books in a single, precise location â€”> brain networks encode our memories
what are the roles of the frontal lobes and hippocampus in memory processing?
what is the function of the hippocampus?
the brain's equivalent of a save button for explicit memories
what is memory consolidation?
the neural storage of a long-term memory
what roles do the cerebellum and basal ganglia play in memory processing?
which parts of the brain are important for implicit memory processing and which parts play a key role in explicit memory processing?
the cerebellum and basal ganglia are important for implicit memory processing and the frontal lobes and hippocampus are key to explicit memory formation
your friend has experienced brain damage in an accident. he can remember how to tie his shoes but has a hard time remembering anything told him during a conversation. what's going on here?
our explicit memories of facts and episodes differ from our implicit memories of skills and classically conditioned repsonses
how do emotions affect our memory processing?
a clear memory of an emotionally significant moment or event
how do changes at the synaptic level affect our memory processing?
long-term potentiation
an increase in a cell's firing potential after brief, rapid stimulation; believed to be a neural basis for learning and memory
which brain area responds to stress hormones by helping create stronger memories?
the amygdala
the neural basis for learning and memory, found at the synapses in the brain's memory-circuit connections, results from brief, rapid stimulation. this is called:
long-term potentiation
how do external cues, internal emotions, and order of appearance influence memory retrieval?
what is priming?
the activation, often unconsciously, of particular associations in memory
what is the encoding specificity principle?
the idea that cues and contexts specific to a particular memory will be most effective in helping us recall it
mood-congruent memory?
the tendency to recall experiences that are consistent with one's current good or bad mood
what is the serial position effect?
our tendency to recall best the last and first items in a list
why do we forget?
what is anterograde amnesia?
an inability to form new memories
what is retrograde amnesia?
an inability to retrieve information from one's past
what is proactive interference?
the forward-acting disruptive effect of prior learning on the recall of new information
what is retroactive interference?
the backward-acting disruptive effect of new learning on the recall of old information
what is repression?
in psychoanalytical theory, the basic defense mechanism that banishes from consciousness anxiety-arousing thoughts, feelings, and memories
what are the ways we forget and how does this happen?
encoding failure-unattended information never entered our memory system; storage decay-information fades from our memory; retrieval failure-we cannot access stored information accurately due to interference or motivated forgetting
how do misinformation, imagination, and source amnesia influence our memory construction and how do we decide whether a memory is real or false?
what is reconsolidation?
a process in which previously stored memories, when retrieved, are potentially altered before being stored again
what is the misinformation effect?
when misleading information has corrupted one's memory of an event
what is source amnesia?
attributing to the wrong source an event we have experienced, heard about, read about, or imagined; at the heart of false memories
what is deja vu?
the eerie sense that we've experienced something before; cues from the current situation may unconsciously trigger retrieval of an earlier experience
how can you use memory research findings to do better in this and other courses?
what are the recommended memory strategies?
  • rehearse repeatedly to boost long-term recall
  • schedule spaced study times
  • spend more time rehearsing or actively thinking about the material
  • make the material personally meaningful with well-organized and vivid associations
  • refresh your memory be returning to contexts and moods to activate retrieval cues
  • use mnemonid devices
  • minimize interference
  • plan for a complete night's sleep
  • test yourself repeatedly

L11 - Learning and Memory 2

October 20, 2020

Chapter 7/8

what is cognition and what are the functions of concepts?
what is cognition?
all the mental activities associated with thinking, knowing, remembering, and communicating
what is the activity of forming concepts?
mentally grouping similar objects, events, ideas, or people
how do we form concepts?
by developing prototypes
what is a prototype?
a mental image or best example of a category; matching new items to a prototype provides a quick and easy method for sorting items into categories
what cognitive strategies assist our problem solving and what obstacles hinder it?
what are algorithms?
a methodical, logical rule or procedure that guarantees solving a particular problem
what are heuristics?
a simple thinking strategy that often allows us to make judgements and solve problems efficiently; more error-prone than algorithms
what is insight?
a sudden realization of a problem's solution; contrasts with strategy-based solutions
what is confirmation bias?
a tendency to search for information that supports our preconceptions and to ignore or distort contradictory evidence
what is mental set?
a prime example of fixation; a tendency to approach a problem in one particular way which has often been successful in the past
what is intuition and how can the availability heuristic, overconfidence, belief perseverance, and framing influence our decisions and judgments?
what is intuition?
an effortless, immediate, automatic feeling or thought, as contrasted with explicit, conscious reasoning
what is availability heuristic?
estimating the likelihood of events based on their availability in memory; if instances come readily to mind, we presume such events are common
what is overconfidence?
the tendency to be more confident than correct
what is belief perseverance?
clinging to one's initial conceptions after the basis on which they were formed has been discredited
what is framing?
the way an issue is posed
how do smart thinkers use intuition?
intuition is analysis "frozen into habit"
it is implicit knowledge
intuition is usually adaptive, enabling quick reactions
people's automatic, unconscious associations with an event can predict their future decisions before they consciously make up their minds
intuition is huge
in solving problems, we benefit by letting our brain work ona problem without thinking about it
what is creativity and what fosters it?
what is creativity?
the ability to produce new valuable ideas
how does brain activity associated with intelligence differ from that associated with creativity?
intelligence tests require convergent thinking
narrowing the available problem solutions to determine the single best solution
creativity tests require divergent thinking
expanding the number of possible problem solutions
what are the 5 components of creativity?
    expertise - well-developed knowledge
    imaginative thinking skills - ability to see things in novel ways, to recognize patterns, and to make connections
    a venturesome personality - seeks new experiences, tolerates ambiguity and risk, and preservers in overcoming obstacles
    intrinsic motivation - being driven more by interest, satisfaction, and challenge than by external pressures
    a creative environment - sparks, supports, and refines creative ideas
what are the structural components of a language?
what is language?
our spoken, written, or signed words and the ways we combine them to communicate meaning
what is a phoneme?
the smallest distinctive sound unit in language
what are morphemes?
the smallest unit that carries meaning in language; might be a word or part of a word
what is grammar?
a system of rules that enables us to communicate with and understand others
how many morphemes are in the word cats? how many phonemes?
2 (cat and s); 4 (c a t s)
what are the milestones in language development and how do we acquire language?
what is the babbling stage?
beginning at about 4 months, the stage of speech development in which the infant spontaneously utters various sounds at first unrelated to the household language
what is the one-word stage?
from age 1 to 2 when a child speaks mostly in single words
what is the two-word stage?
beginning at age 2, a child speaks mostly two-word statements
what is telegraphic speech?
a child speaks like a telegram using mostly nouns and verbs
what is the difference between receptive and productive languages and when do children normally hit these milestones in language development?
receptive language skills at 4 months, after that they develop productive language skills
what was the premise of researcher Chomsky's work in language development?
maintained that all languages share a universal grammar and humans are biologically predisposed to learn the grammar rules of language
why is it so difficult to learn a new language in adulthood?
our brain's critical period for language learning is in childhood when we can absorb language structure almost effortlessly; as we move past that stage our brain can not learn a new language easily
what brain areas are involved in language processing and speech?
what is aphasia?
impairment of language, usually caused by left hemisphere damage either to the Broca's area or to Wernicke's area
what is broca's area?
controls language expression; an area of the frontal lobe, usually in the left hemisphere, that directs the muscle movements involved in speech
what is wernicke's area?
controls language reception; a brain area involved in language comprehension and expression; usually in the left temporal lobe
A is the part of the brain that, if damaged, might impair your ability to speak words. damage to B might impair your ability to understand language
broca's area; wernicke's area
what is the relationship between thinking and language and what is the value of thinking in images?
what is linguistic determinism?
a hypothesis that language determines the way we think
what is mental practice and how can it help you prepare for an upcoming event?
mental practice uses visual imagery to mentally rehearse future behaviors, activating some of the same brain areas used during the actual behaviors; visualizing the details of the process is more effective than visualizing only your end goal

L14 - Intelligence 2

November 3, 2020

Chapter 10

how do psychologists define intelligence and what are the arguments for?
what is intelligence?
the mental potential to learn from experience, solve problems, and use knowledge to adapt to new situations; the ability to solve problems
what is general intelligence (g)?
a general intelligence factor that underlies specific mental abilities and is therefore measured by every task on an intelligence test
what is factor analysis and why is it important to general intelligence?
a statistical procedure that identifies clusters of related items; people often have outstanding abilities in one area, but not another
what was Thurstone's primary mental abilities theory?
our intelligence may be broken down in 7 factors therefore a single g score is not as informative as 7 different scores
how does the brain relate to intelligence?
what is the correlation between brain size and intelligence?
r = 0.33; the larger the frontal and parietal lobes, the more intelligent you are; Einstein had a disproportionately large parietal lobe
what is the correlation between brain size and speed?
r = 0.5 for g and the speed of talking; women's brains are smaller but they are faster
how do Gardner's and Sternberg's theories of multiple intelligences differ and what criticisms have they faced?
Gardner has proposed 8, maybe 9, relatively independent intelligence, what does this mean?
intelligence domains are viewed as multiple abilities that come in different packages
what is savant syndrome?
a condition in which a person otherwise limited in mental ability has an exceptional specific skill, such as in computation or drawing
what is Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence?
what is analytical intelligence?
academic problem-solving; assessed by intelligence tests which present problems with a single right answer; the closest thing to "IQ" because it is book-smarts and academic competence
what is creative intelligence?
demonstrated in innovative smarts, like the ability to demonstrate novel ideas
what are the four axes of creative intelligence?
expertise; imagination; a venturesome personality; motivation
what is practical intelligence?
required for everyday tasks that are not well-defined and may have many possible solutions
what specific points do Gardner and Sternberg differ on?
multiple abilities can contribute to life success and differing varieties of giftedness add spice to life and challenges for education
what are criticisms of multiple intelligence theories?
high intelligence might help you get into a profession but it won't make you successful once you're there
how does the existence of savant syndrome support Gardner's theory of multiple intelligences?
people with savant syndrome have limited mental ability overall but possess one or more exceptional skills, which, according to Gardner, suggests that out abilities come in separate packages rather than being fully expressed by one general intelligence that encompasses all of our talents
what are the four components of emotional intelligence?
what is emotional intelligence?
the ability to perceive, understand, manage, and use emotions
why do some people believe emotional intelligence should be part of creative intelligence?
recognizing others emotions, predicting emotional responses, displaying emotions, and using emotions adaptively are very intuitive
what is an intelligence test and what is the difference between achievement and aptitude tests?
what is an intelligence test?
a method for assessing an individual's mental aptitudes and comparing them with those of others using numerical scores
what 3 criteria must an IQ test meet for it to be worthwhile?
they must be standardized, reliable, and valid
what is an achievement test?
a test designed to assess what a person has learned
what is an aptitude test?
a test designed to predict a person's future performance; aptitude is the capacity to learn; classic IQ test
when and why were intelligence tests created and how do today's tests differ from early intelligence tests?
what is mental age?
a measure of intelligence test performance; the chronological age that most typically corresponds to a given level of performance
what did Binet hope to achieve by establishing a child's mental age?
hoped that the child's mental age would help identify appropriate school placements
what is the Stanford-Binet?
the widely used american revision of Binet's original intelligence test
what is IQ?
originally defined as the ratio of mental age (ma) to chronological age (ca) multiplied by 10; contemporary tests show the average performance for a given age assigned on a scale of 100
what is the IQ of a 4-year-old with a mental age of 5?
(5/4)100= 125
what is the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale?
the WAIS and its companion versions for children are the most widely used intelligence tests; contain verbal and nonverbal subsets
an employer with a pool of applicants for a single available position is interested in testing each applicant's potential. to help her decide whom she should hire, she should use an A test. that same employer wishing to test the effectiveness of a new job training program would be wise to use a B test
aptitude; achievement
what is a normal curve and what does it mean to say that a test has been standardized and is reliable and valid?
what is standardization?
defining uniform testing procedures and meaningful scores by comparison with the performance of a pretested group
what is a normal curve?
the bell-shaped curve that describes the distributions of many physical and psychological attributes
what is reliability?
the extent to which a test yields consistent results, as assessed by the consistency of scores on two halves of the test, on alternating forms of the test, or on retesting
what is validity?
the extent to which a test measures or predicts what it is supposed to
what is content validity?
the extent to which a test samples the behavior that is of interest
what is predictive validity?
the success with which a test predicts the behavior it is designed to predict; it is assessed by computing the correlation between test scores and the criterion behavior
what are three criteria that a psychological test must meet in order to be widely accepted?
a psychological test must be standardized, reliable, and valid
how stable are intelligence scores over the life span and how does aging affect crystallized and fluid intelligence?
what is a cohort?
a group of people sharing a common characteristic, such as from a given time period
what crystalized intelligence?
our accumulated knowledge and verbal skills; tends to increase with age
what is fluid intelligence?
our ability to reason speedily and abstractly; tends to decrease during late adulthood
what are the traits of those at the low and high intelligence extremes?
what is an intellectual disability?
a condition of limited mental ability, indicated by an intelligence test score of 70 or below or difficulty adapting to the demands of life
what is down syndrome?
a condition of mild to severe intellectual disability and associated physical disorders caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21
what evidence points to a genetic influence on intelligence and what is heritability?
what is heritability?
the proportion of variation among individuals that we can attribute to genses
how does heritability relate to environmental effect?
heritability of intelligence is about 50%; it takes a lot of environment enrichment over a long time to make a modest difference in things like poverty environments
how and why do the genders differ in mental ability scores?
is there a difference in "standard" IQ between genders?
no, boys and girls test the same
how do the genders differ on non-standard tests?
girls outperform in spelling, verbal agility, nonverbal memory, sensation tests, emotional intelligence, reading comprehension, and arithmetic; boys outperform in abstract math problems and spatial skills
how and why do racial and ethnic groups differ in mentala bilty?
what are the explanations for persistent racial disparities in IQ scores?
intelligence not being properly defined or tested
molecular gentics confirms that race does storngly associeate with ontentinetn of predominant accentual orgin
racial bias seems to overestimate performance of minorities
stero-type threat
intelligence is not being properly defined or tested; nature and nurture; social and environmental factors

L15 - Motivation 1

November 6, 2020

Chapter 11

how do psychologists define motivation and from what perspectives do they view motivated behavior?
what is motivation?
a need or desire that energizes and directs behavior
what are four perspectives for viewing motivated behaviors?
  • instinct theory - genetically predisposed behaviors
  • drive-reduction theory - how we respond to our inner pushes
  • arousal theory - finding the right level of stimulation
  • Maslow's hierarchy of needs - priority of some needs over others
    • what is an instinct?
    a complex behavior that is rigidly patterned throughout a species and is unlearned
    what is drive-reduction theory?
    the idea that a physiological need creates an aroused tension state that motivates an organism to satisfy the need
    what is homeostasis and why is this an aim of drive-reduction?
    a tendency to maintain a balanced or constant internal state; for example, if we are water-deprived, our thirst drives us to drink and to restore the body's normal state
    what is an incentive?
    a positive or negative environmental stimulus that motivates behavior
    what is stimulation?
    reward centers in the brain activate just for learning or experiencing something new
    what can chronic stimulation lead to?
    stress, jitters, and loss of IQ points
    what is Yerkes-Dodson law?
    the principle that performance increases with arousal only up to a point, beyond which performance decreases
    performance peaks at lower levels of arousal for difficult tasks and at higher levels for easy or well-learned tasks. How might this phenomenon affect runners, anxious test-takers, and how might the performance of anxious students be affected by relaxation training?
    runners tend to excel when aroused by competition; high anxiety in test-takers may disrupt their performance; teaching anxious students how to relax before an exam can enable them to performs better
    what is Maslow's hierarchy of needs?
    beginning at the base with physiological needs that must first be satisfied before higher-level safety needs and then psychological needs can become active
    how do instinct theory, drive-reduction theory, and arousal theory contribute to our understanding of motivated behavior?
    instincts and evolutionary psychology help explain the genetic basis for our unlearned species-typical behavior. from drive-reduction theory, we know that our physiological needs create an aroused state that drives us to reduce the needs.
    after hours of driving alone in an unfamiliar city, you finally see a diner, although it looks deserted and a little creepy, you stop because you are really hungry. how would maslow's hierarchy of needs explain your behavior?
    according to maslow, our drive to meet the physiological needs of hunger and thirst take priority over safety needs, prompting us to take risks at times in order to eat
    what physiological factors produce hunger?
    what happens if people are hungry?
    the most basic need tends to dominate; if you're hungry, the only thing you're thinking about is food
    what does it actually mean to be hungry?
    we are motivated by food; you can feel hunger pains
    how does glucose impact hunger?
    what is glucose?
    the form of sugar that circulates in the blood and provides the major source of energy for body tissues
    what does an increase in insulin do?
    diminish blood glucose by converting it to stored fat; if blood glucose levels drop, your brain will automatically trigger hunger
    how does the brain trigger hunger?
    blood vessels connected to the hypothalamus respond to blood chemistry and other incoming information; appetite hormone is ghrelin
    what is the set point?
    the point at which your weight thermostat is supposedly set; when your body falls below this weight, increased hunger and a lowered metabolic rate may combine to restore the lost weight
    what is the settling point?
    we have fairly constant weight because we maintain a fairly constant caloric intake and energy expenditure
    what is basal metabolic rate?
    the body's resting rate of energy expenditure
    hunger occurs in response to A blood glucose and B levels of ghrelin
    low; high
    what cultural and situational factors influence hunger?
    how do taste preferences impact hunger?
    what taste preferences are genetic and universal?
    sweet and salty
    how does culture impact taste preferences?
    people who repeatedly sample an initially novel fruit drink or unfamiliar food typically experience increasing appreciation for the new taste
    what situations impact eating?
    why do we eat more around other people?
    the presence of others tends to amplify our natural behavior tendencies
    what is unit bias?
    offered a supersized portion, people will consume more calories
    how does food variety stimulate eating?
    when foods are abundant, eating more provides more nutrients
    after an eight-hour hike without food, your long-awaited favorite dish is placed in front of you, and your mouth waters in anticipation. Why?
    you have learned to respond to the sight and aroma that signal the food about to enter your mouth; both physiological cues, like low blood sugar, and psychological cues, like anticipation of the meal, heighten your experienced hunger
    what factors predispose some people to become and remain obese?
    why do we require less food to maintain our weight once we become fat?
    fat has a lower metabolic rate than muscle does so it takes less food energy to maintain
    do our genes predispose us to eating more or less?
    there is a genetic influence on body weight: people's weights resemble those of their biological parents and genes explain two-thirds of our varying body mass
    how important are environmental factors to our body weight?
    what is the impact of sleep loss?
    the levels of leptin and ghrelin rise
    what is the impact of social influence?
    the correlation among friends' weights showed if one friend was obses, the other was likely to become obese as well
    why can two people of the same age, height, and activity level maintain the same weight, even if one of them eats much less than the other does?
    individuals have very different set points and genetically influenced metabolism levels, causing them to burn calories differently
    what are the common eating disorders outside of obesity?
    anorexia
    dieting for weight loss that becomes an obsession and continues even after health weight is reached
    bulimia
    marked by fluctuations in weight and characterized by a repeating cycle of overeating followed by purging
    binge-eating
    like bulimia but without purging, and instead, the onset of self-loathing
    what are the estimates of obesity?
    2.2 billion adults are overweight, 400 million being obese
    why is it so hard to lose fat?
    every pound of fat contain about 3500 calories
    how are fat cells influenced by weight?
    fat cells don't only multiply when you gain weight, they also enlarge; when you lose weight they won't disappear, only shrink
    how do hormones influence human sexual motivation?
    what does it mean to be asexual?
    having no sexual attraction to others
    what is testosterone?
    the most important male sec hormone; both males and females have it, but the additional testosterone in males stimulates the gorwth of male sx organcs during the fetal period, and the development of male sex characteristics during puberty
    what is estrogen?
    sex hormones like estradiol that are secreted in greater amounts by females than by males and contribute to female sex characteristics; in nonhuman female mammals, estrogen levels peak during ovulation, promoting sexual receptivity
    what is the human sexual response cycle and how do sexual dysfunctions and paraphilias differ?
    when was the first research of sex conducted and what did we learn?
    Masters and Johnson conducted these experiments in the 1950s and they wrote a textbook on the 4 stages of sexual arousal
    what is the sexual response cycle?
    the four stages of sexual responding
    what are the four stages?
    excitement
    the genital areas become engorged with blood
    plateau
    excitement peaks as breathing, pulse, and blood pressure rates continue to increase
    orgasm
    muscle contractions appear all over the body and are accompanied by further increases in pulse, breathing, and blood pressure rates
    what is the benefit of orgasm?
    helps propel semn toward the uterus and draw it inward, thus increasing retention of deposited sperm and increasing the chance of conception
    what did freud think there were 2 different types of orgasm?
    vaginal was "the right kind" and clitoral was "the neurotic kind" but this was a destroyed myth because women and men have the same type of orgasm
    resolution
    the body gradually returns to its unaroused state and men enter the refactory period
    what is the refractory period?
    a resting period after orgasm during which a man cannot achieve another orgasm
    what are sexual dysfunctions?
    a problem that consistently impairs seual arousal or functioning
    what is erectile disorder?
    inability to develop or maintain an erection due to insufficient blood flow to the penis
    what is female orgasmic disorder?
    distress due to infrequently or never experiencing orgasm
    what is paraphilias?
    sexual arousal from fantasies, behaviors, or urges involving nonhuman objects, the suffering of self or others, or nonconsenting persons
    how can sexually transmitted infections be prevented?
    why has there been a decrease in the amount of sex young people are having for the first time in history?
    this 10% decrease is most likely due to the internet access
    what is AIDS?
    a life-threatening, sexually transmitted infection caused by the human immunodeficiency virus; it depletes the immune system, leaving the person vulnerable to infections
    the inability to complete the sexual response cycle may be considered an A. exhibitionism would be considered B
    sexual dysfunction; paraphilia
    from a biological perspective, AIDS is passed more readily from women to men than from men to women. true or false?
    false, AIDS is transmitted more easily and more often from men to women
    how do external and imagined stimuli contribute to sexual arousal?
    why does men liking sexually stimulating material typically lead to disinterest in their partners?
    the more sexually stimulating, the less arousal it instills â€”> this is the same process of habituation in which you create a tolerance to this material
    can exposure to sexually explicit material have adverse effects?
    rape acceptance
    has increased views belief in the false idea that women enjoy rape, and have increased male viewers' willingness to hurt women
    devaluing partner
    leads people to devalue their own partners and relationships
    diminished satisfaction
    reading unlikely scenarios may create expectations that few men and women can fulfill
    what factors influence our sexual motivation and behavior?
    influences include biological factors such as sexual maturity and sex hormones, psychological factors such as environmental stimuli and fantasies, and socio-cultural factors such as the values and expectations absorbed from family and the surrounding culture
    what factors influence teenagers' sexual behaviors and use of contraceptives?
    how does minimal communication about birth control influence sex?
    teens who talk freely with parents and their partners are more likely to use contraceptives
    how does guilt related to sexual activity impact sex?
    sexual inhibitions or ambivalence can restrain sexual activity, but also reduce planning for birth control
    how does alcohol use impact sex?
    mose sexual hook-ups occur under influence; by depressing the brain centers that control judgement, inhibition, and self-awareness, alcohol disarms normal restraints
    how do mass media norms of unprotected promiscuity impact sex?
    the more sexual content adolescents and young adults view or read, the more likely they are to perceive their peers as sexually active, develop sexually permissive attitudes, and experience early intercourse
    which factors contribute to unplanned teen pregnancies?
    alcohol use, unprotected sex, and mass media models
    what are some overall statistics about sex in america?
    Daily porn viewing
  • 50-70% of men
  • 30-85% of women
  • Most sexually active women use a vibrator
    Have sex at least once per week lowers menâ€™s risk of
  • Heart disease by 30%
  • Diabetes by 40%
  • More than 15% of college women now claim they are something other than heterosexual
    • what has research taught us about sexual orientation?
    what is sexual orientation?
    an enduring sexual attraction toward members of one's own sed, the other sex, or both sexes; about 4% of the population is homosexual; only in 2001 did homosexuality become dropped from the list of mental disorders
    what factors have researchers found to have an effect on sexual orientation?
    size of certain cell clusters in the hypothalamus, prenatal hormone exposure, for men-having multiple older biological borthers
    where does homosexuality come from?
    how does family influence sexuality?
    there's a strong correlation between the more older brothers a man has, the more likely he is to be gay; homosexual men tend to have more homosexuals on their mother's side of the family because these genes make women more desirable then men
    is being gay a choice?
    sexuality is mainly due to hormones in utero

the behavior is atypical of the person's culture; behaviors may be deviant in one context but not another; standards for behavior change not just with place but also with time
what does it mean to be dysfunctional?
interferes with the person's life or threatens the wellbeing of others
what was the revolutionary cause for treating people with mental disorders morally by giving them therapy, medication, activity, and cleanliness?
the recognition of the role of syphilis in madness
how do the medical model and the biopsychosocial approach influence our understanding of psychological disorders?
what is the medical model?
the concept that disease, in this case psychological disorders, have physical causes that can be diagnosed, treated, and cured, often through treatment in a hospital
what is epigenetics?
the study of environmental influences on gene expression that occur without a DNA change
in addition to the medical model, what else might provide a way for mental illness?
environment, personality (habits, social skills, deviations from societal norms), or anything a medical doctor cannot fix
how and why do clinicians classify psychological disorders, and why do some psychologists criticize the use of diagnostic labels?
what does classification aim to do?
predict the disorders future corse, suggest appropriate treatment, and prompt research into its causes
what is the most common tool for describing disorders and estimating how often they occur?
the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5); DSM defines a diagnostic process that is based on symptoms, there is no casual basis for the diagnosis; the process of diagnosis is a very well constrained and extensive analysis of diagnoses indicates that clinications do tend to produce similar diagnoses (AKA the DSM is very reliable)
is the DSM valid?
the dsm is increasingly capturing normals; what started with 60 disorders has now expanded to more than 400 separate disorders; roughly one quarter of americans would meet the criteria for at least one of them in any year
what are the benefits of diagnosis?
aid in communicating between caregivers, provides a basis for comparing experimental groups, and provides sufferers with information about what they can expect
what is the value, and what are the dangers, of labeling individuals with disorders?
the dangers of labeling are that people may begin to act as though they have been labeled and the labels can trigger assumptions that will change our behavior; in reality our violence against people with mental disorders is far more common than violence by people with mental disorders
how many people have a psychological disorder and is poverty a risk factor?
how many people have a psychological disorder?
just over 1 in 4 adults suffer from a diagnosable mental disorder in a given year in the US;
what increases vulnerability to mental disorders?
poverty-related stresses can help trigger disorders, but disabling disorders can also contribute to poverty; poverty and disorders are often a chicken-and-egg situation and it's hard to know which came first
how do generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and phobias differ?
what are anxiety disorders?
psychological disorders characterized by distressing, persistent anxiety or maladaptive behaviors that reduce anxiety
what is generalized anxiety disorder?
an anxiety disorder in which a person is continually tense, apprehensive, and in a state of autonomic nervous system arousal
what is panic disorder?
an anxiety disorder marked by unpredictable, minutes-long episodes of intense dread in which a person experiences terror and accompanying chest pain, choking, or other frightening sensations. often followed by worry over a possible next attack
what is phobia?
an anxiety disorder marked by a persistent, irrational fear and avoidance of a specific object, activity, or situation
what is OCD?
what is obsessive-compulsive disorder?
a disorder characterized by unwanted repetitive thoughts, actions, or both
who is most likely to suffer from OCD?
teens and young adults; as they mature their OCD tends to decrease in severity
what is PTSD?
what is posttraumatic stress disorder?
a disorder characterized by haunting memories, nightmares, social withdrawal, jumpy anxiety, numbness of feeling, and/or insomnia that lingers for four wees or more after a traumatic experience
what does the dual-track mind underpin with trauma disorders?
those with active limbic systems seem to be more vulnerable to traumatic effects; there is evidence from twin studies that these states are highly heritable
how does gender affect trauma disorders?
women are roughly twice as likely as men to develop PTSD, regardless of gender, however, most victims do not seem to be traumatized
how do conditioning, cognition, and biology contribute to the feelings and thoughts that mark anxiety disorders, OCD, and PTSD?
what 3 learning processes can contribute to the development of anxiety?
stimulus generalization, negative reinforcement, and observational learning
stimulus generalization?
when we are justifiably frightened by some event in a first case, we may generalize that stimulus to inappropriate environments
negative reinforcement?
if we successfully avoid a situation that causes us anxiety, we will negatively reinforce that behavior
observational learning?
we may also learn fear simply by watching someone else be afraid
how does biological predisposition to fear encourage anxiety?
our innate fears due to the survival of our ancestors makes us generally more anxious about these things
what are somatoform disorders?
physical ailments with no physical cause
what is hypochondria?
a relatively common somatoform disorder wherein people interpret a normal symptom as instead being one of a dreaded disease
how do major depressive disorder, persistent depressive disorder, and bipolar disorder differ?
what is major depressive disorder?
a disorder in which a person experiences, in the absence of drugs or another medical condition, two or more weeks with five or more symptoms, at least one of much must be either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure
what are the key features of MDD?
exhibit symptoms of another disorder, such as substance abuse of anxiety; women as nearly twice as vulnerable as men; most MDD spontaneously resolves; most MDD is antedated by a sad or stressful event; diagnosis of depression is occurring more and more frequently, earlier and earlier too
what is the biological basis for MDD?
depressive disorders are highly heritable (having a sibling or parent with the disorders increases your likelihood to 1/5, having a twin increases it to 1/2); brain activity is markedly reduced in depressed vs manic states
what 2 neurotransmitters have a role in mood disorders?
norepinephrine
boosts arousal and mood; production is low during depression and high during mania
serotonin
certain serotonin-controlling genes have been implicated in depression
how does learned helplessness contribute to mood disorders?
women seem to be much more vulnerable to learned helplessness than men; the result of feeling helpless combined with pessimistic, overgeneralized, guilt-ridden emotions implies that our explanatory style when dealing with stressors or sad events may underpin our susceptibility to depression; HOWEVER,negative events, viewed by a pessimistic individual, makes individuals behave a certain way to create more negative events thus perpetuating the cycle
what is mania?
a hyperactive, wildly optimistic state in which dangerously poor judgement is common
bipolar disorder?
a disorder in which a person alternates between the hopelessness and lethargy of depression and an overexcited state of mania
why is BP more disabling than MDD?
as manic phases often exercise very poor judgement and the irritability making it difficult to offer them advice, BP claims twice as many lost work days annually
what are dissociative disorders?
ailments of consciousness; they often reflect a kind of Freudian suppression, but no a person's whole consciousness
what is dissociative identity disorder (DID)?
two or more distinct personalities alternately control the person's behavior; there is strong evidence that the disease is manufactured because there were only 2 diagnoses per decade until the 1960s and then in the 1980s there were ten thousand times that many
who might be manufacturing this?
patients might do it to themselves since it became popular is movies, therapists might do it by asking leading questions (making DID iatrogenic)
what are mood disorders?
"the common cold" of mental illness because they are relatively unserious
major depressive disorder
non-manic depression
bipolar disorder
manic depression
are the symptoms adaptive?
some depression might be advantageous to inhibit certain dangerous goals, after negative life changes is considered healthy, seasonal affective disorder is ancestral
how does suicide differ between groups?
the US had mid-range rates; whites are twice as likely to commit as blacks; women are more likely to attempt but men are more likely to succeed; suicide rates rise dramatically for late adulthood men; rates are higher for the wealthy than poor, divorced or single than married, the non-religious than religious, and the homosexual adolescent than the heterosexual adolescent
how can the biological and social-cognitive perspectives help us understand depressive disorders and bipolar disorder?
  • many behavioral and cognitive changes accompany depression
  • depression is widespread
  • women's risk of major depression is nearly double men's
  • most major depressive episodes self-terminate
  • stressful events related to work, marriage, and close relationships often precede depression
    what is rumination?
    compulsive fretting; overthinking about our problems and their causes
    • what factors increase the risk of suicide and what do we know about nonsuicidal self-injury?
    national diffferences, racial differenes, gender differences, age differences and trends, other group differences, day of the week differences
    how do chronic and acute schizophrenia differ?
    what is chronic schizophrenia?
    symptoms usually appear by late adolescence or early adulthood; as people age, psychotic episodes last longer and recovery periods shorten
    what is acute schizophrenia?
    can begin at any age, frequently occurs in response to an emotionally traumatic event, and has extended recovery periods
    what are general symptoms of schizophrenia?
    disorganized thought, delusions, disturbed perceptions, and inappropriate affect
    when does schizophrenia usually have its onset?
    young-late adolescents to the early twenties; men a hit earlier and more severly than women; sometimes it will appear suddenly; if the onset is slow and over many years then it's usually chronic and is more dangerous
    what findings are fairly consistent across schizophrenias?
    changes in dopamine signaling, abnormal brain activity and anatomy, prenatal viral infection, and genetics
    dopamine levels
    often unregulated in schizophrenia
    brain structures
    abnormally low brain activity in the frontal lobe, activity in the thalamus is vigorous during hallucinations, the amygdala is active and the cortex and the thalamus are smaller
    prenatal environment
    low birth weight, oxygen deprivation during delivery, and maternal malnutrition are all known risk factors for schizophrenia; if a virus was contracted during the second trimester of the pregnancy, the child may be at greater risk for schizophrenia if: they were born after a flu epidemic, they were born in densely populated areas, are born after flu season, the mother caught the flu during pregnancy, and if blood tests high for antiviral antibodies (the odds of schizophrenia if you catch the flu double to 2%)
    genetics
    the risk for schizophrenia jumps to 10% among those who have siblings or a parent with the disorder; it jumps fiftyfold if the sibling is an identical twin; it jumps sixtyfold if the twin shares the placenta (but just the normal 10% if they don't share a placenta)
    how do we handle people with depression and psychosis in regards to the law?
    what is antisocial personality disorder (APD)?
    as known for the terms "psychopath" and "sociopath," people with APD seemingly lack a conscience
    what is the genetic component to APD?
    children who shows aggressive and antisocial behaviors when confronted with aversive stimuli are likely to channel this into things like courageous heroism, adventurism, star-athleticism, and CEOs

L21 - Mental Illness 2

Chapter 15/16

how do psychotherapy and the biomedical therapies differ?
what is psychotherapy?
treatment involving psychological techniques; consists of interactions between a trained therapist and someone seeking to overcome psychological difficulties or achieve personal growth
what is the eclectic approach?
an approach to psychotherapy that uses techniques from other forms of therapy
why does Freud deserve credit for establishing the value of working through mental problems with a professional?
the basic tenant of psychanalysis is that mental health is promoted by alleviating id-ego-superego conflicts
what are the goals and techniques of psychoanalysis and how have they adapted in psychodynamic therapy?
what is psychoanalysis?
freud believed the patient's free associations, resistances, dreams, and transferences, released previously repressed feelings, allowing the patient to gain self-insight
what are the goals?
aim to bring patients' repressed or disowned feelings into conscious awareness in order to reduce growth-impeding inner conflicts
what are the techniques?
what is resistance?
the blocking from consciousness of anxiety-laden material; resistance implies a defense mechanisms which is the result of repression
what is interpretation?
the analyst's noting supposed dream meanings, resistances, and other significant behaviors and events in order to promote insight
what is transference?
the patient's transfer to the analyst of emotions linked with other relationships
what is psychodynamic therapy?
therapy deriving from the psychoanalytic tradition; views individuals as responding to unconscious forces and childhood experiences, and seeks to enhance self-insight
what remains from psychoanalysis?
the importance of the subconscious and the provision of insight to the patient by the analyst
what are the basic themes of humanistic therapy and what are the specific goals and techniques of Rogers' client-centered approach?
what are insight therapies?
a variety of therapies that aim to improve psychological functioning by increasing a person's awareness of underlying motives and defenses
what is client-centered therapy?
a humanistic therapy in which the therapist uses techniques such as active listening within a genuine, accepting, empathic environment to facilitate clients' growth
what is active listening?
empathic listening in which the listener echoes, restates, and clarifies
what is unconditional positive regard?
a caring, accepting, nonjudgmental attitude to help clients develop self-awareness and self-acceptance
how does this viewpoint differ from psychoanalysis?
focuses on the future rather than dwelling on the past, expects patients to take immediate responsibility for their failings instead of repressing them, and growth instead of curing is the focus
how does basic assumption of behavior therapy differ from the assumptions of psychodynamic and humanistic therapies and what techniques are used in exposure therapies and aversive conditioning?
what are behavior therapies?
therapy that applies learning principles to the elimination of unwanted behaviors
what is counterconditioning?
behavior therapy procedures that use classical conditioning to evoke new responses to stimuli that are triggering unwanted behaviors
what are exposure therapies?
behavioral techniques such as systematic desensitization and virtual reality therapy, that treat anxieties by exposing people to the things they fear and avoid
what is systematic desensitization?
a type of exposure therapy that associates a pleasant relaxed state with gradually increasing anxiety-triggering stimuli
what is virtual reality exposure therapy?
an anxiety treatment that progressively exposes people to electronic simulations of their greatest fears
what is aversive conditioning?
a type of counterconditioning that associates an unpleasant state with an unwanted behavior
what is the main premise of therapy based on operant conditioning principles and what are the views of its proponents and critics?
what is token economy?
an operant conditioning procedure in which people earn a token of some sort for exhibiting a desired behavior and can lter exchange their tokens for various privileges or treats
what are the goals and techniques of cognitive therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy?
what is cognitive therapy?
therapy that teaches people new, more adaptive ways of thinking; based on the assumption that thoughts intervene between events and our emotional reactions
what is cognitive-behavioral therapy?
a popular integrative therapy that combines cognitive therapy with behavior therapy
what are the aims and benefits of group and family therapies?
what is group therapy?
therapy conducted with groups rather than individuals, permitting benefits from group interaction
what are the advantages?
increased social contact, recognition that others suffer from the same problem, and much lower cost per patient
what is family therapy?
therapy that treats the family as a system; views and individual's unwanted behavior as influenced by, or directed at, other family members
does psychotherapy work and how can we know?
why are client testimonials for therapy not persuasive?
people often enter therapy in crisis, clients believe the therapy will be effective, clients want to believe the therapy was worth the effort, clients generally speak kindly of their therapists
what is meta-analysis?
a procedure for statistically combining the results of many different research studies
what can outcome measures do?
include patient reports but are "stronger" if objective measurements of success are made such as readmission to the hospital or survival rates
what have efficacy studies showed?
about two thirds of those receiving psychotherapy for nonpsychotic mental disorders show improvement
what is the comparison between those who successfully enroll in therapy vs those who wait on lists?
above 80% of people who make it to therapy are above the 50th percentile overall; there is significant improvement
is it cost effective?
data suggests that well-timed therapy can significantly reduce these long-term costs in a very cost-effective way
do different therapeutic approaches have different efficacy?
noâ€” psychoanalysis has been shown to be quite effective despite its complete lack of scientific grounding
how do we encourage evidence-based practice?
therapy should be rigorously evaluated, applied by clinicians who are mindful of their skills, and tailored to each patient's unique situation
are some psychotherapies more effective than others for specific disorders?
what is evidence-based practice?
clinical decision making that integrates the best available research with clinical expertise and patient characteristics and preferences
how do alternative therapies fare under scientific scrutiny?
two effects of alternative therapies may serve to convince patients that these methods work:
people tend to recover with time in any event from most mental disorders and the placebo effect will cause those patients to feel better
why does EMDR work?
associating the traumatic memories in a safe and reassuring context that provides emotional distance from the experience is a lot like the behaviorial technique of exposure therpy, so the ritual of moving light combined with the eye tracking makes for a robust placebo effect
why does light exposure help depression?
exposure to bright light is effective at reducing symptoms of SAD, and brain scans reveal that the body's arousal regions are activated by light
what three elements are shared by all forms of psychotherapy?
what are 3 benefits of psychotherapy?
hope for demoralized people, a new perspective leading to new behavior, and an empathetic trusting,m caring relationship
what is therapeutic alliance?
a bond of trust and mutual understanding between a therapist and client, who work together constructively to overcome the client's problem
how do culture and values influence the therapist-client relationship?
patients from a collectivist culture may do better when paired with like-minded therapists
what are the drug therapies and how do double-blind studies help researchers evaluate a drug's effectiveness?
what is psychopharmacology?
the study of the effects of drugs on mind and behavior
what are antipsychotic drugs?
drugs used to treat schizophrenia and other forms of severe thought disorder; typically act on dopamine and its receptors
what are anti-anxiety drugs?
drugs used to control anxiety and agitation by reducing the sympathetic nervous system
what are antidepressant drugs?
drugs used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, obsessive-compulsive disorders, and post-traumatic stress disorders; target the serotonin system
what are the not-well-understood phenomena regarding SSRIs?
the amount of serotonin stuck in synapses begins to rise almost immediately, the antidepressant effect can take four weeks to kick in, one drug may not work for everyone
how weak is their effect?
about 75% of the effect is placebo
why are they not a panacea?
low efficacy and sexual dysfunction suck
why would a mood stabilizer be a better drug for BP than an antidepressant?
BP patients on lithium have about 1/6 the suicide risk as those not taking a mood stabliizer
how are brain stimulation and psychosurgery used in treating specific disorders?
what is electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)?
a biomedical therapy for severely depressed patients in which a brief electric current is sent through the brain of an anesthetized patient; the seizure calms the overactive areas of the brain central to depression; in 4/10 patients where it works, the relapse within six months
what is repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS)?
the application of repeated pulses of magnetic energy to the brain; used to stimulate or suppress brain activity
what is psychosurgery?
surgery that removes or destroys brain tissue in an effort to change behavior
what is a lobotomy?
a psychosurgery used to calm uncontrollably emotional or violent patients; the procedure cuts the nerves connecting the frontal lobes to the emotion-controlling centers of the inner brain
what is posttraumatic growth?
positive psychological changes as a result of struggling with extremely challenging circumstances and life crises
what is the nature of psychological disorders?
why have the numbers of ADHD sextupled?
increased from and average of 3% per year to 5.5% per year because ADHD is a real disorder

L3 - The Nervous System 1

September 18, 2020

Chapter 2

why are psychologists concerned with human biology?
to understand behavior, we need to study how biological, psychological, and social systems interact
what do phrenology and psychological biologists perspectives have in common?
they share a focus on the links between the brain and behavior
what are neurons and how do they transmit information?
neurons, or nerve cells, are the building blocks of the system; consist of a cell body and its branching fibers

    how do they transmit information?
    dendrite fibers receive information and conduct it towards the cell body. the cell's single axon fier passes the message through its terminal branches to other neurons or to muscles/glands

    what's the difference between dendrite fibers and axon fibers?
    dendrites listen, axons speak

    dendrites are typically short, axons can be long (projecting several feet into the body)

    what do axons look like?
    they may be long, projecting several feet through the body

    what is myelin and how is it related to axons?
    some axons are encased in myelin, which is a fatty tissue that insulates them and speeds their impulses

    how long do myelin last?
    it's laid down for about 25 years and while that's happening, neural efficiency, judgment, and self control grow

    what happens if the myelin sheath degenerates?
    MS results because communication to muscles slows, eventually resulting in loss of muscle control

    what is the purpose of a glial cell?
    also known as"glue" cells, they support the billions of nerve cells by providing nutrients and myelin, guide neural connection, and mop up ions and neurotransmitters

    do glial cells communicate at all?
    they play a role in learning and thinking; by "chatting" with neurons, they participate in information transmission and memory

    how does the ratio of glial cells to neurons differ?
    in more complex animal brains, the proportion of flia to neurons increases; this is because the more complex a bran, the more thought processing, and the more essential the communication between glia and neurons become

    what happens when neurons are triggered by chemical signals?
    the neuron will fire an impulse, or a brief electrical charge that travel down its axon now as the action potential

    how fast is a neural impulse?
    depending on the type of fiber, an impulse can travel at speeds of 2 mph to 200 mph

    when neurons generate electricity from a chemical activity, how are neurons exchanged?
    the fluid outside the membrane has positively chaged sodium ions, the fuild on the inside has negtive charged potassium ions (this is restin potential). once the neuron fires an impules, the gates open, and positively charged sodium ions come rushing in. the depolarization cauese the axons to open like dominoes and so begins the refractory period, or a resting hpase in whit the nueron pumps psotiive ions back outside

    what happens when the excitatory signals exceed the inhibitory signals?
    the combined signals cause an action potential. however, there is a certain threshold for this level of stimulation, and if the threshold is too far passed, the neural impulse won't fire; the impulse intensity never changes

    when a neuron fires an action potential, the information travels through the axon, the dendrites, and the cell body, but not in that order. what is the correct order?
    dendrites, cell body, axon

    how does our nervous system allow us to experience the difference between a slap and a tap on the back?
    strong stimuli cause more neurons to fire and to fire more frequently than weak stimuli

how do nerve cells communicate with other nerve cells?
there's a meeting point called the synapse â€”> the axon terminal of one neuron is separated from the receiving neuron by the synaptic gap

    what happens when the action potential reaches knob-like terminals at an axon's end?
    it triggers the release of chemical messengers called neurotransmitters

      what does the action potential pathway look like?
      the neurotransmitters cross the synaptic gap and bind to the receptor sites of the receiving neuron â€”> for an instant, tiny channels unlock at the receiving site and electrically charged atoms flow in, exciting or inhibiting the receiving neurons readiness to fire

        what happens after the action potential causes the neuron to fire?
        the excess neurotransmitters drift away, are broken down by enzymes, or are reabsorbed by the sending neuron in a process called reuptake

    what happens in the synaptic gap?
    neurons send neurotransmitters across this tiny space between one neuron's terminal branch and the next neuron's dendrite or cell body

    what is reuptake?
    reuptake occurs when excess neurotransmitters are reabsorbed by the sending neuron

    if not reuptake, what other processes take place with neurotransmitters?
    they can also drift away or be broken down by enzymes

how do neurotransmitters influence behavior and how do drugs/chemicals affect them?
drugs and chemicals affect brain chemistry, either by exciting or inhibiting neuron's firing

    how do agonist molecules increase neuron action?
    can increase production and release of neurotransmitters, block reuptake in the synapse, they may be similar enough to the neurotransmitters to bind to its receptor and mimic it, and they may produce a temporary "high" by amplifying normal sensations

    how do antagonist molecules decrease neron action?
    blocking production or release of neurotransmitters, enough like the neurotransmitters to occupy its receptor site and block its effect, but are not similar enough to stimulate the receptor

    serotonin, dopamine, and endorphins are all chemical messengers called
    neurotransmitters

what are the functions of the nervous system's main divisions, and what are the 3 main types of neurons?
    what makes up the peripheral nervous system (PNS)?
    the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system

      what is the somatic nervous system?
      the control center that enables voluntary control of skeletal muscles

      what is the autonomic nervous system (ANS) and what are the components that make it up?
      controls our glands and internal organs, thus influencing glandular activity, heatbeat, and digestion; it operates autonomously. and it is made of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous system

        what does the sympathetic nervous system do?
        arouses and expends energy; accelerate heartbeat, raise blood pressure, slow digestion, raise blood sugar, cool you with perspiration

        what does the parasympathetic nervous system do?
        conserves energy and calms you

    what makes up the central nervous system (CNS)?
    the brain and the spinal cord

      what is the function of the spinal cord?
      working as a two-way highway between the PNS and the brain, the spinal cord's ascending neural fibers send up sensory info and the descending neural fibers send back motor-control information

      what do motor neurons do?
      carry outgoing messages from the CNS to muscles and glands

      what do sensory neurons do?
      carry incoming messages from sensory receptors to the CNS

      what do interneurons do?
      communicate within the CNS and process information between ingoing and outgoing messages

    what bodily change does your ANS direct before and after you give an important speech?
    your ANS sympathetic division will arouse you. It accelerates your heartbeat, raises your blood pressure and blood sugar, and cools you with perspiration. After the speech, your ANS parasympathetic division will reverse these effects

how does the endocrine system work?
the endocrine system's glands secrete hormones, which travel through the bloodstream and affect tissues and the brain

    what's the difference between the endocrine and the nervous system's hormone production
    the endocrine messages trudge along the bloodstream at a slower pace than the neurotransmitters in the nervous system, but the endocrine reactions outlast those of the nervous system

    how does the ANS work for the endocrine system?
    in a moment of danger, the ANS orders the adrenal glands to release epinephrine and norepinephrine

    what does the pituitary gland do?
    located in the core of the brain, the pituitary releases growth hormones and oxytocin

    why is the pituitary gland called the "master" gland?
    responding to signals from the hypothalamus, the pituitary releases hormones that trigger other endocrine glands to secrete hormones, which, in turn, influences the brain and behavior

how do neuroscientists study the brain's connections to behavior and mind?
    fMRI?
    tracks successive images of brain tissue to show brain function

    PET scan?
    tracks radioactive glucose levels in the brain

    MRI scan?
    uses magnetic fields and radio waves to show brain anatomy

what structures make up the brainstem and what are the functions of the brainstem, thalamus, reticular formation, and cerebellum?
    what does the brain stem look like and what are its components?
    the brainstems begins where the spinal cord swells slightly after entering the skull. the swelling is called the medulla, which controls heartbeat and breathing, and above the medulla lies the pons, which coordinates movement and controls sleep

    what is the thalamus?
    sitting atop the brainstem, the thalamus is an egg-shaped structure that acts as the brain's sensory control center. it receives information from all sense except smell and routes it to higher brain regions that deal with seeing, hearing, tasting, and touching

    what is the reticular formation?
    between the ears lies the RF which is a neuron network that extends from the spinal cord up to the thalamus

    what is the cerebellum?
    short for "little brain," the cerebellum enable nonverbal learning and skill memory

    in what brain region would damage be most likely to disrupt A: your ability to skip rope? B: your ability to hear and taste? C: could perhaps leave you in a coma? and D: cut off the very breath and heartbeat of your life?
    cerebellum, thalamus, reticular formation, medulla

what are the limbic system's structures and functions?
the hippocampus processes conscious, explicit memories, and releases hormones while the amygdala is linked to emotion

    electrical stimulation of a cat's amygdala provokes angry reactions. which autonomic nervous system division is activated by such stimulation?
    the sympathetic nervous system

what are the functions of the various cerebral cortex regions?
    what is the cerebral cortex?
    a thin layer of interconnected neural cells cover the cortex; the wrinkles of the cortex tripple its surface area

    how many lobes are there?
    4 which include: the frontal lobes (behind your forehead), the parietal lobes (top and to the rear), the occipital lobes (back of your head), and the temporal lobes (above the ears)

    what is the motor cortex?
    area at the rear of the frontal lobes that controls voluntary movements

    what is the somatosensory cortex?
    area at the front of the parietal lobes that registers and processes body touch and movement sensations

    what are association areas?
    not involved in primary or secondary motor functions, association areas are involved in higher mental functions such as learning, remembering, thinking, and speaking

    which area of the human brain is most similar to that of less complex animals? which part of the human brain distinguishes us from animals?
    the brainstem; the cerebral cortex

    our brain's A cortex registers and processes body touch and movement sensations. The B cortex controls our voluntary movements
    somatosensory; motor

to what extent can a damaged brain recognize itself, and what is neurogenesis?
    what is plasticity?
    the brain's ability to modify itself after damage

    what can brain damage be traced to?
    severed brain and spinal cord neurons usually do not regentrate OR some brain functions seem preassigned to specific areas

    can neural tissue reorganize?
    in response to damage, constraint-induced therapy aims to rewire brains and improves the dexterity of a brain-damaged person

    what is neurogenesis?
    the formation of new neurons

what do split brains reveal about the functions of our two brain hemispheres?
    what is corpus callosum?
    a large band of neural fibers connecting the two brain hemispheres and carrying messages between them

    what is split brain?
    a condition resulting from surgery that isolates the brain's two hemispheres by cutting the fibers connecting them

    if we flash a red light to the right hemisphere of a person with a split-brain and flash a green light to the left hemisphere, will each observe its own color?
    yes

    will the person be aware the colors differ?
    no

    what will the person verbally report seeing?
    green

    almost all right-handers process speech in the A hemisphere; most left-handers process speech in the B hemisphere
    left; left

what is the place of consciousness in psychological history?
what is consciousness?
our awareness of ourselves and our environment
what is the "dual processing" being revealed by today's cognitive neuroscience?
what is cognitive neuroscience?
the interdisciplinary study of the brain activity linked with our mental processes
how might conscious experience happen?
synchronized actitivy from the brain; if a stimulus activates enough nbrain-wide coordinated neural acitivty is crosses a threshhold for consciousness
what is the difference between a weak and strong stimulus?
a weak sitmulus may activate local visualized cortex while a stronger signal may activate other brain areas like those involved with language, attention, and memory
what is dual processing
when information is simultaneously processed in a separate conscious/conscious track; this means we know more than we think
what is blindsight?
a condition in which a person can respond to a visual stimulus without consciously experience it
those working in the interdisciplinary field called A study the brain activity associated with perception, thinking, memory, and language
cognitive neuroscience
what are the mind's two tracks and what is dual processing?
our mind has separate unconscious and conscious tracks that perform dual processing â€”> organizing and interpreting information simultaneously
how does selective attention direct our perceptions?
what is parallel processing?
enables your mind to take care of routine business
what sequential processing?
best for solving new problems
what is the purpose of selective attention?

what are sensation and perception and what do we mean by bottom-up processing and top-down processing?
sensation
the process by which sensory receptors detect stimuli
perception
the process of organizing and interpreting sensory information
bottom-up processing
analysis that begins with the sensory receptors and works up to the brain's integration of sensory inormation
top-down processing
information processing guided by higher-level mental processes, as when we construct perceptions drawing on our experience and expectations
what three steps are basic to all our sensory systems?
all our senses:
  • receive sensory stimulation, often using specialized receptor cells
  • transform that stimulation into neural impulses
  • deliver the neural information to our brain
    • what is transduction?
    conversion of one form of energy into another
    what is psychophysics?
    the study of relationships between the physical characteristics of stimuli, such as their intensity, and our psychological experience of them
    what is the rough distinction between sensation and perception?
    sensation is the bottom-up process by which our sensory receptors and our nervous system receive and represent stimuli; perception is the top-down process in which our brain creates meaning by organising and interpreting what our sense detect
    how do absolute thresholds and difference thresholds differ and what effect, if any, do stimuli below the absolute threshold have on us?
    what are absolute thresholds?
    the minimum stimulation necessary to detect a particular light, sound, pressure, taste, or odor 50 percent of the time
    what is signal detection theory?
    a prediction of when we will detect weak signals
    what are subliminal stimuli?
    signals you can't detect 50 percent of the time; they are below your absolute threshold
    what is priming?
    the activation of certain associations, thus predisposing one's perception, memory, or response
    what are difference thresholds?
    the minimum difference a person can detect between any two stimuli half the time; this increases with the size of the stimulus
    what is weber's law?
    for an average person to perceive a difference, two stimuli must differ by a constant minimum percentage

    absolute threshold is the minimum stimulation needed to detect a particular sound 50 percent of the time. subliminal stimulation happens when our sensory system processes the sound of the approaching object. a difference threshold is the minimum difference needed to distinguish between two sounds
    what is the function of sensory adaptation?
    what is sensory adaptation?
    diminished sensitivity as a consequence of constant stimulation

    behind the pupil is a transparent lens that focuses incoming light rays into an image on the retina, a multi layered tissue on the eyeball's sensitive inner surface
    the lens focuses the rays by changing its curvature and thickness in a process called accomodation

    the chemical reaction would spark neural signals, activating nearby bipolar cells
    the bipolar cells would activate the ganglion cells, whose axons twine together to form the optic nerve
    the optic nerve is an information highway that connects your thalamus and is ready to distributie the information it receives from the eye
    where the optic nerve leaves the eye, there are no receptor cells â€”> this is your blindspot

  • cluster around the fovea, the retina's area of central focus

  • enable you to perceive color but in dim light they become ineffective so you don't see color

  • rods share bipolar cells which send combined messages
  • rods enable black and white visions and are sensitive to dim light

    a top-down process in which we recognize objects without being deceived by changes in the color, brightness, shape, or size
